captions.text:
00:09
COMM: Shaun Ellis from Devon in england has

integrated himself into a pack of wild wolves.
The 47 year old lives like one of the predators.

Only eating meat and barely washing in order
to be accepted.

00:23
SHAUN: The actual integration of the pack

itself began when the wolves in particular
were only a few days of age. I still consider
myself to be part of that family.

00:33
COMM: Shaun who's become known as the Wolf

Man for his unusual research techniques, is
now passing on his skills to wife Isla.

00:45
COMM: The pair met through their shared love
of native american culture.

00:49
ISLA: Yeah it was actually love at first sight,

I always had this image in my head of my dream
man, my ideal man and obviously that's an

image, just a dream because you don't think
you'll ever meet that person but I guess I

was fortunate enough and lucky enough to meet
the man of my dreams.

01:05
COMM: Unlike your average household pet, these

wolves aren't on a diet of pedigree chum.
Instead devouring huge legs of horse meat
once a week.

01:13
SHAUN: All their social position, where they

are on the carcass would have all been established
long before we got here with the food.

01:21
SHAUN: So we've got our enforcer, our alpha

female, or decision making female and then
our dominant male heading off into the background
there.

01:34
SHAUN: I don't think there's anything special

about me but there's certainly something special
in the animals I work with, and they don't

deserve the maligning reputation that they've
got. They're not vicious creatures that would

attack us by the full moon. And it's ironic
that still to this day we have people that

call them savage ruthless killer, but I've
come to know and love them as family.

comments.text:
He 'integrated' with them from their infancy, they don't hunt because he 
supplies all of their food, and they've never had to fight other packs for 
territory (the average lifespan of wolves in Yellowstone is only about 6 
years directly because of this). Notice how easily they accepted his wife, 
presumably after they'd already grown to adulthood. These wolves are 
basically tame.﻿

i have a hybrid and he is one of the most loyal respectful friends i have. 
he can tell if ive had a bad day he will come up put his head in my lap and 
just be calm and just be there for me. his coat has caught my tears more 
than once. then he can tell when i want to play he really likes those times 
bc im a bigger guy 5'8 200lbs almost equal in size and weight (not in 
power) so we rough house alot. ive seen him be so loving and gentel with me 
then when someone he hasnt accepted comes in jumps up between us full on 
attack mode. those r times im scared of him bc thats not my friend thats 
the wild side. i tell my guest go to ur knees and dont move let him come to 
u. to this day hes never bit anyone that listened to me.﻿

A true friend!! Some people wouldn't be so kind and so willing to help, 
he's a Hero! 
I'm not too steady on my feet sometimes. Neuropathy in my legs gives me

We are Blessed to have such wonderful friends🐾
I'm hope you'll be ok, sounds painful!!
comments.author: JeannetteMarieSgili

comments.text:
+JeannetteMarieSgili my friend did something amazing yesterday. i was doing 
a video and i fractured my ankle and ruined my left calf muscle (no surgery 
im staying off it this weekend) he herd my yelp ran from his room to see 
what happened. this brought me to tears, he saw i couldnt walk so he ran 
about 60 yards to my neighbors (he likes them) started barking and 
stractching the door to get there attention. he lead the neighbor to me and 
helped me inside. i couldnt get up so while he didnt save my life he def 
helped me in my few times of need. so this weekend he gets a steak sat and 
sun. he hasnt left my side since this happened. i know humans that wouldnt 
help someone but my wild wolf helped me. even though its illegal to have 
him in georgia ill risk the jail time bc hes part of my family. hes right 
now beside me resting his head in my lap watching youtube with me (idk if 
hes watching the videos or just protecting me, either way i enjoy times 
like this where its just us relaxing. i honestly think he is my guardian 
(not angel bc im atheist) animal. the reason we get along so well is bc my 
spirit animal is a wolf.
comments.author: MLGTroy1

comments.text:
Great! Good to let him be as natural and as his ancestors, he gets a treat! 
I don't have "pets" either. My 3 dogs are friends who share my life, they 
are all rescues. I'm not sure who rescued who, I think it's mutual. I have 
to separate them when they eat. It's common sense. I think that's what most 
people don't understand, common wolf/dog sense. It comes natural to me. 
I've known and loved many wolves and wolfdogs. I've loved animals all my 
life, I understand them more than people really. An animal will always act 
as they are. People act other than they truly are. I respect them so they 
respect me too. I've never been bit out of anger only in play. I do know a 
trick if Bear or any fellow animal gets too rough with their mouth. It's 
worked every time. Just ask my friend, I'd be more than happy to share this 
"trick"! 
I know how to greet them as an equal, as a friend. 
It's so wonderful to find someone who has a friend like my Bear, and I 
think you understand! I do not have pets no, they are my family. And by 
your comments I believe we think alike in our ways. Let our furry friends 
be as they are, when they seem aggressive it's out of fear or protecting 
the ones they love. I've found if Bear has a problem with a person then I 
should be wary of them too. I trust his judgement. I'd love to talk with 
others who have these special family members, with others who understand🐾
Thanks!!
comments.author: JeannetteMarieSgili

comments.text:
+JeannetteMarieSgili i feed my friend (hes not a pet) steak every friday. 
no seasoning i heat it to body temp (around 98 degrees) and throw it in the 
yard let him have his fun
comments.author: MLGTroy1

comments.text:
Mine is the same, it's those who don't listen and respect him that he has 
trouble with, he's my protector, and he like me demands respect. 
You see I have PTSD. So he is also my service companion. I sleep at night 
because I know he's watching over me. I wouldn't trade him for the world! 
He once saved my baby nephew from an attack by another dog, now that scared 
me because I was afraid the other dog had been hurt badly, but turns out 
she was fine, just four punctures. But he shook the big pit like a rag 
doll. I too have been extremely cautious when introducing new people, but 
if there's a problem it's because they do not approach him right. It's not 
about dominance at all. It's about respect. One should never approach any 
animal with the intention of dominating it. Or "braeaking" them, that means 
breaking their Spirit. A broken Spirit is a broken heart.
comments.author: JeannetteMarieSgili

comments.text:
Just because they "appreciate Native American culture" doesn't make them 
any less white, dude. OP is right, when you see these extreme videos, it's 
either white people doing it for fun, or foreigners doing it because they 
were raised on it.

Native Americans rarely did shit like this though. We appreciate nature and 
understand that we have no say in it. We do not own nature, we do not visit 
it, it owns us, it is home. Nature is family. That being said, we usually 
respect the distance of our more dangerous relatives.

you.
